qas.question: How did many philosophers and theologians at Illinois Divinity School view Whitehead's work?
What expert on Whitehead delivered a lecture at the school to reject Whitehead's ideas?

context: However, <a0_0><a5_0><b9_0><b12_0>Mathews<b12_0/><a0_0/>' frustration with Whitehead's books did not negatively affect his interest<b9_0/><a5_0/>. In fact, there were numerous philosophers and theologians at <a1_0>Chicago's Divinity School<a1_0/> that <a6_0><b10_0>perceived the importance of what Whitehead was doing without fully grasping all of the details and implications<b10_0/><a6_0/>. In <a3_0>1927<a3_0/> they invited one of America's only Whitehead experts – <a2_0><a7_0><b11_0>Henry Nelson Wieman<b11_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/> – to Chicago to give a lecture explaining Whitehead's thought. <a8_0>Wieman's lecture was so brilliant that he was promptly <a4_0>hired<a4_0/> to the faculty and taught there for twenty years<a8_0/>, and for at least thirty years afterward Chicago's Divinity School was closely associated with Whitehead's thought.
